column55: THIS PROPOSAL FOR A TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE IS SUBMITTED ON BEHALF OF A CONSORTIUM OF NON-PROFIT ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS IN RESPONSE TO NASA COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT NOTICE NNJ15548000C (CAN)  RELEASED OCTOBER 30  2015. THE CONSORTIUM IS LED BY B
column90:
Y1-Agree $149,999
 This proposal is designed to capture data in-flight, concentrate that data, and build a framework for collaboration with researchers.  In doing so, the entire field of space medicine will change from a field that depends on case reports to a field that can truly embrace evidence based medicine.
 AIMS
 â ¢ Aim 1: Analyze and publish data from SARS-CoV-2 testing.
 a. Assess the risk of SARS-CoV-2 infection in SpaceX employees stratified by exposure risks
 b. Determine the range and severity of disease due to SARS-CoV-2 infection, including asymptomatic infections
 c. Inform SpaceX back to work policies
 d. Characterize immunological and demographic features of asymptomatic infections and presence of reinfections
 e. Build an internal framework for data collection and data privacy
 f. Build an interface for data visualization and analysis
 g. Submit findings as original research to a peer reviewed journal
 
 â ¢ Aim 2: Develop a design criteria review and architecture for end-to-end medical data collection from the human, transfer to the ground, storage, and analysis for and in-flight healthcare.
 a. Scope the medical system that is needed for Starship, including all components
 b. Develop a trade for sensors that would provide valuable telemetry
 c. Determine which data needs real-time telemetry and which data can be stored for review later
 d. Integrate data collection and telemetry into Starship architecture 
 e. Propose a sentinel piece of telemetry that can be integrated into crew Dragon and propose a process for integration
 f. Develop privacy constraints for data storage
 g. Propose a model for including medical researchers
 h. Complete a critical design review that includes all aspects of a medical system and present this design review to SpaceX stakeholders
 Iterate towards a final, acceptable path forward
 
 DELIVERABLES
 â ¢ Aim 1: Written article describing research on COVID-19. 
 â ¢ Aim 2: Design criteria review that describes the medical system, and will address sensor selection, telemetry, data storage, etc.
 
 MILESTONES
 â ¢ Aim 1: 
 12/1 Summarize existing data and submit for publication 
 12/15 Run of company wide antibody study and PCR sequencing of viral RNA
 3/15 Run of company wide antibody study and PCR sequencing 
 4/15 Data review
 5/15 Submit publications
 â ¢ Aim 2: 
 12/31 Selection of physiologic parameters of interest for short duration spaceflight
 1/31 Trade analysis of COTS / modified COTS wearable bio-sensors
 3/31 Consent & process approval for collection of biometric data from private passengers
 4/31 Wearable sensor flight verification / testing, deployment of flight certified hardware for initial testing
 6/31 Medical sensor crew ease of use testing completion & down-selection
 9/31 Implementation of electronic record system for storing anonymized biometric data

column55: THIS PROPOSAL FOR A TRANSLATIONAL RESEARCH INSTITUTE IS SUBMITTED ON BEHALF OF A CONSORTIUM OF NON-PROFIT ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS IN RESPONSE TO NASA COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT NOTICE NNJ15548000C (CAN)  RELEASED OCTOBER 30  2015. THE CONSORTIUM IS LED BY B
column90:
The goals of this proposal have been developed with an overall timeline of 3 years, with the 
 understanding that, if this proposal is approved and reasonable progress is maintained over the 
 execution period, the grant is expected to be renewed on a yearly basis over this timeframe.
 Specific Aim 1: Enable the development and execution of human research in commercial spaceflight 
 opportunities at SpaceX
 (a) Establish a research capability at SpaceX to effectively and efficiently interface with all 
 stakeholders in the pursuit of human research opportunities in commercial spaceflights
 (b) Support all of the research-related work specific to the I4 mission and any other commercial 
 missions that are contracted over the grant period
 (c) Pursue and promote research as a core component of future commercial spaceflight missions
 Specific Aim 2: Develop research infrastructure to support data management, integration of multiple 
 data sources, and streamlining of standard measures
 (a) Support the development of a data repository that can host all data from commercial spaceflight 
 research, including facilitating the transfer and uploading of research, and relevant operational 
 and medical data to the database
 (b) Provide feedback and relevant operational expertise to help inform the development of standard 
 measures for commercial spaceflight in coordination with TRISH, including preliminary assessment of 
 hardware needs that would support collection of standard measures
 Specific Aim 3: Flight certification of new research hardware
 (a) Formulate a risk posture at SpaceX for commercial missions with respect to 
 commercial-off-the-shelf electronics, in order to have a clear path towards hardware certification
 (b) Provide relevant operational and hardware feedback to PIs in the development of their in-flight 
 experiment
 (c) Work with certification engineers to perform hardware qualification testing campaigns and 
 obtain flight certification for research hardware Milestones, Deliverables and Timeline
 Deliverables for year 1 include:
 - Creating the necessary infrastructure for human research, including obtaining Federal-Wide 
 Assurance (FWA) approval, IRB approvals, and ensuring up to date human-subject training for all 
 relevant personnel
 - Supporting all of the research development for I4, including pre-flight, in-flight, and 
 post-flight protocols, and execution of the experiments
 - Transferring all research and relevant operational data into the research repository
 - Collaborating in a timely manner with experiment PIs on the preparation of manuscripts for 
 publication
 - Promoting commercial spaceflight research through relevant PR opportunities in coordination with 
 all relevant stakeholders
 
 Key Milestones for the project for year 1 include: (1) launch of I4 mission, currently scheduled 
 for Sept 15, 2021, and (2) successful completion of all post-flight data collection and data 
 transfer to the respective PIs, estimated to occur before end of 2021. Upcoming milestones for 2022 
 calendar year will include development of a research portfolio for a 2nd upcoming commercial 
 spaceflight (not yet confirmed) and the publication of research from the I4 mission. Upon 
 confirmation of the next SpaceX commercial flight, a similar set of deliverables will be assembled 
 and included as part of the research work. The overall expectation is that a similar workflow and 
 set of deliverables will be included as part of research work in any future commercial missions that are contracted and executed within the grant
 period.
